text: I was at an org that used Seismic. Strong tagging / content surfacing but the reporting and analytics left something to be desired.

text:
How do we write a brief that works? 

I'm having difficulties making a comprehensive brief for in-house writers and freelancers. Any tips on how to make it more helpful & explanatory?

elements.text:
How do we write a brief that works? 

I'm having difficulties making a comprehensive brief for in-house writers and freelancers. Any tips on how to make it more helpful & explanatory?

attachments.title: What is an SEO Content Brief (And How to Write One) - Topic Blog
attachments.text: Learn how to write an SEO content brief so you (or your writers) can create better SEO content, FASTER. Includes strategies and tools.
attachments.fallback: Topic Blog: What is an SEO Content Brief (And How to Write One) - Topic Blog

text:
Here's the bare minimum I expect to see in a brief as a writer.

Title:
Primary keyword:
Secondary keywords:
Estimated word count range (should be wide):
Competitor links (if available):

Blog post structure
Introduction: Mention points you like the writer to discuss:
Similar for other H2s and H3.
Conclusion

text:
Here's one from <@U017WRJTKF1>. It's practical and straight to the point [template included]:

<https://contentfolks.substack.com/p/how-to-create-a-content-brief|https://contentfolks.substack.com/p/how-to-create-a-content-brief>

attachments.title: cf #14: the ABC of a great content brief
attachments.text: A great content brief focuses on three things: Audience, Brand, and Context.
attachments.fallback: cf #14: the ABC of a great content brief

elements.text: . It's practical and straight to the point [template included]:

text:
Here's what I cover in my onboarding brief (for freelancers only ... in-house writers get a VERY comprehensive six-week onboarding program).

*Best practices for writing:* 

• Define your audience. Pick one of the following: 
    ◦ Persona 1
    ◦ Persona 2
    ◦ Etc.
• Make sure the topic maps to one of our primary categories:
    ◦ Topic 1 (this maps to [product])
    ◦ Topic 2 (this maps to [product])
    ◦ Etc.
• Can we look at the topic through a [category] lens?
• Can we weave in a statistic from one of our quarterly reports?
    ◦ Report link
    ◦ Report link
    ◦ Etc.
• Make sure your article adds value: 
    ◦ Does it give the reader an "ah-ha" moment/change their thinking? OR
    ◦ Does it give the reader tactical tips they can implement today?
*Brand + writing guidelines:*
• Please review our brand voice [here].
• Please review our brand archetype [here].
• Use AP Style (if you know it).
• Speak to the reader as “you.” 
• Use active voice vs. passive voice.
• Use contractions to keep the tone friendly.
• Keep your paragraphs short.
• Use bulleted lists to keep the copy skimmable.
• Vary your sentence length.
*Links:*
• Please use two external links per blog post.
• Our editorial team will add internal links.
*Submission guidelines + payment terms:* 
• Write in a Google doc and give editing access to [email of editor].
• When you submit your draft, *include your invoice and a completed W9.*
• We pay upon [payment terms].
*For freelancers who are ghostwriting:*
You’re free to use this blog in your portfolio. However, you are NOT allowed to post to social media and tell people you wrote it.

*For freelancers who are getting a byline (subject matter experts):* 
• Include a headshot.
• Include a 2-sentence author bio.
• _Ex) Andy is a content writer and editor. He's an unashamed map geek, hoops enthusiast, and Goldfish cracker aficionado._
All submissions go through an editorial review process. We reserve the right to make changes to meet our editorial standards and match our brand guidelines. We'll make all reasonable efforts to give you an opportunity to review edits before publishing.

Questions on any of this? Reach out to our [title, name].

P.S. If it's a BRAND new writer, I've found that hopping on a call with them to walk through this brief is helpful vs. just sending the brief.

Then, on top of this brief, you can choose to send them individual content/SEO/campaign briefs.

Define your audience. Pick one of the following:
Make sure the topic maps to one of our primary categories:
Can we look at the topic through a [category] lens?
Can we weave in a statistic from one of our quarterly reports?
Make sure your article adds value:
Does it give the reader an "ah-ha" moment/change their thinking? OR
Does it give the reader tactical tips they can implement today?
Use AP Style (if you know it).
Use active voice vs. passive voice.
Use contractions to keep the tone friendly.
Use bulleted lists to keep the copy skimmable.
Please use two external links per blog post.
Our editorial team will add internal links.
Write in a Google doc and give editing access to [email of editor].
include your invoice and a completed W9.
You’re free to use this blog in your portfolio. However, you are NOT allowed to post to social media and tell people you wrote it.
For freelancers who are getting a byline (subject matter experts):
Ex) Andy is a content writer and editor. He's an unashamed map geek, hoops enthusiast, and Goldfish cracker aficionado.

All submissions go through an editorial review process. We reserve the right to make changes to meet our editorial standards and match our brand guidelines. We'll make all reasonable efforts to give you an opportunity to review edits before publishing.

Questions on any of this? Reach out to our [title, name].

P.S. If it's a BRAND new writer, I've found that hopping on a call with them to walk through this brief is helpful vs. just sending the brief.

Then, on top of this brief, you can choose to send them individual content/SEO/campaign briefs.

text:
Good list <@U012DRHAC2X>.

  Would be helpful to see:
• breakdown of content funnels that worked well for your clients 
• examples of content that worked for each stage of the funnel that inevitably led to conversions 
• How content led to paid users - how to go from free trial to paid customers 
•  How to setup, track and measure content campaigns

elements.text: breakdown of content funnels that worked well for your clients
examples of content that worked for each stage of the funnel that inevitably led to conversions
How content led to paid users - how to go from free trial to paid customers
How to setup, track and measure content campaigns
